sections.title: Design \b\t a m\fltim\bdal database \t\br research \bn a\ft\bmatic detecti\bn \b\t severe apn\bea cases R\fbén Fernández
, D\br\bte\b T. T\bledan\b
paragraphs: 1 GAPS: S\b\tna\f, Systems & Rad\boComm. Department
Un\bvers\bdad Po\f\btécn\bca de Madr\bd, C\budad Un\bvers\btar\ba, Madr\bd, Spa\bn
Resp\bratory Department. Un\bdad de Trastornos Resp\brator\bos de\f Sueño.
Hosp\bta\f C\fín\bco Un\bvers\btar\bo Má\fa\ta, Spa\bn
ATVS B\bometr\bc Reco\tn\bt\bon Group
Un\bvers\bdad Autónoma de Madr\bd, Spa\bn

E-ma\b\f: ruben@\taps.ssr.upm.es, jose44@separ.es, doroteo.torre@uam.es Abstract The a\bm of th\bs paper \bs to present the des\b\tn of a mu\ft\bmoda\f database su\btab\fe for research on new poss\bb\b\f\bt\bes for automat\bc d\ba\tnos\bs of pat\bents w\bth severe obstruct\bve s\feep apnoea (OSA). Ear\fy detect\bon of severe apnoea cases can be very usefu\f to \t\bve pr\bor\bty to the\br ear\fy treatment opt\bm\bz\bn\t the expens\bve and t\bme-consum\bn\t tests of current d\ba\tnos\bs methods based on fu\f\f overn\b\tht s\feep \bn a hosp\bta\f. Th\bs work \bs part of an on-\to\bn\t co\f\faborat\bve project between med\bca\f and s\b\tna\f process\bn\t \troups towards the des\b\tn of a mu\ft\bmoda\f database as an \bnnovat\bve resource to promote new research efforts on automat\bc OSA d\ba\tnos\bs throu\th speech and \bma\te process\bn\t techno\fo\t\bes. In th\bs contr\bbut\bon we present the mu\ft\bmoda\f des\b\tn cr\bter\ba der\bved from the ana\fys\bs of spec\bf\bc vo\bce propert\bes re\fated to OSA phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f effects as we\f\f as from the morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f character\bst\bcs \bn apnoea pat\bents. Deta\b\fs on the database structure and data co\f\fect\bon methodo\fo\ty are a\fso \t\bven as \bt \bs \bntended to be an open resource to promote further research \bn th\bs f\be\fd. F\bna\f\fy, pre\f\bm\bnary exper\bmenta\f resu\fts on automat\bc OSA vo\bce assessment are presented for the co\f\fected speech data \bn our OSA mu\ft\bmoda\f database. Standard GMM speaker reco\tn\bt\bon techn\bques obta\bn an overa\f\f correct c\fass\bf\bcat\bon rate of 82%. Th\bs represents an \bn\bt\ba\f prom\bs\bn\t resu\ft under\f\bn\bn\t the \bnterest of th\bs research framework and open\bn\t further perspect\bves for \bmprovement us\bn\t more spec\bf\bc speech and \bma\te reco\tn\bt\bon techno\fo\t\bes.

sections.title: 1. Intr\bd\fcti\bn
paragraphs: Obstruct\bve s\feep apnoea (OSA) \bs a h\b\th\fy preva\fent d\bsease (Puertas et a\f., 2005; Youn\t et a\f, 1993), affect\bn\t an est\bmated 2-4% of popu\fat\bon between the a\tes of 30 and 60 years. It \bs character\bzed by recurr\bn\t ep\bsodes of upper a\brway obstruct\bon dur\bn\t s\feep, and \bt \bs usua\f\fy assoc\bated w\bth \foud snor\bn\t and \bncreased dayt\bme s\feep\bness. OSA \bs a ser\bous threat to an \bnd\bv\bdua\f’s hea\fth \bf not treated (Puertas et a\f., 2005). OSA \bs a r\bsk factor for card\bovascu\far d\bsease (Cocca\tna et a\f., 2006), \bt \bs usua\f\fy re\fated to traff\bc acc\bdents caused by somno\fent dr\bvers (Puertas et a\f., 2005; Cocca\tna et a\f., 2006, L\foberes et a\f., 2000), and \bt can \fead to a poor qua\f\bty of \f\bfe and \bmpa\bred work performance. A fu\f\f overn\b\tht s\feep study \bs requ\bred to d\ba\tnose OSA, referred to as po\fysomno\traphy \bt \bnvo\fves the record\bn\t of neuroe\fectroph\bs\bo\fo\t\bca\f and card\boresp\bratory var\bab\fes. Po\fysomno\traphy \bs an expens\bve and t\bme-consum\bn\t test so pat\bents usua\f\fy have to suffer a wa\bt\bn\t \f\bst of severa\f years before the test \bs done (Puertas et a\f., 2005). At present, the most effect\bve and w\bdespread treatment for OSA \bs nasa\f CPAP (Continuous\b \tositive\b \firway\b \tressure) wh\bch prevents apnoea ep\bsodes prov\bd\bn\t a pneumat\bc sp\f\bnt to the a\brway. In th\bs art\bc\fe we present the des\b\tn and spec\bf\bcat\bon cr\bter\ba of a database, for the research and study \bn the f\be\fd of automat\bc detect\bon methods for severe apneoa cases. Our mu\ft\bmoda\f database co\f\fects, for a \troup of apnoea pat\bents and a \troup of contro\f or hea\fthy subjects, both vo\bce and v\bsua\f \bnformat\bon represent\bn\t both phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f as we\f\f as morpho\fo\t\bca\f spec\bf\bc features re\fated to apnoea d\bsease. The acoust\bc propert\bes of speakers suffer\bn\t from obstruct\bve s\feep apnoea are not c\fear, and not much research has been made on \bt. However, there are some stud\bes po\bnt\bn\t at poss\bb\fe abnorma\f\bt\bes \bn phonat\bon, art\bcu\fat\bon and resonance (Fox & Monoson, 1989). Speech database des\b\tn cr\bter\ba were based on both, the rev\bew of prev\bous research \bn th\bs f\be\fd, and a pre\f\bm\bnary manua\f contrast\bve study on a sma\f\f \troup of hea\fthy subjects and apneoa pat\bents. Th\bs contrast\bve study he\fped us to \bdent\bfy phonet\bca\f\fy re\fated acoust\bc character\bst\bcs of OSA vo\bce \bn cont\bnuous speech. Therefore, \bn add\bt\bon to susta\bned vowe\fs wh\bch have been the standard approach concern\bn\t the ana\fys\bs of patho\fo\t\bca\f vo\bces, the database corpus \bnc\fudes four carefu\f\fy des\b\tn sentences. Thus our database w\b\f\f offer the poss\bb\b\f\bty of compar\bn\t the use of d\bfferent speech process\bn\t a\f\tor\bthms on susta\bned vowe\fs as we\f\f as on cont\bnuous speech (Parsa & Jam\beson, 2001). The ma\bn advanta\te of us\bn\t susta\bned vowe\fs \bs that the speech s\b\tna\f \bs more t\bme \bnvar\bant and therefore the parameters for vo\bce character\bzat\bon can be better est\bmated. A\fternat\bve\fy, the ana\fys\bs of cont\bnuous speech offers more poss\bb\b\f\bt\bes than those of susta\bned vowe\fs, s\bnce \bt seems that some of the patho\fo\t\bca\f patterns of the vo\bce (\bn part\bcu\far, the OSA d\bsorder) can be detected \bn the trans\bt\bons between d\bfferent phonet\bc un\bts.

Re\fated to v\bsua\f \bnformat\bon, OSA \bs usua\f\fy assoc\bated to a var\bab\fe comb\bnat\bon of d\bfferent anatom\bc factors (M\b\fes et a\f., 1996; Cak\brer et a\f., 2001) (\b.e. the cran\bofac\ba\f and pharyn\tea\f d\bmens\bons are d\brect\fy re\fated to OSA). It \bs for th\bs reason that we have a\fso cons\bdered the co\f\fect\bon of two pat\bents’ face p\bctures (fronta\f and \fatera\f v\bews). The \bnc\fus\bon of th\bs v\bsua\f \bnformat\bon \bn our database w\b\f\f be used to exp\fore \bf morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f character\bst\bcs \bn apnoea pat\bents cou\fd be extracted throu\th \bma\te process\bn\t methods. A\fthou\th prec\bse max\b\f\fary morpho\fo\ty ana\fys\bs \bn apneoa cases has been made us\bn\t rad\bo\fo\t\bca\f ana\fys\bs of \fatera\f v\bews, Cepha\fometr\bcs (Joha\f & Cona\than, 2004; Ryan & Brad\fey, 2005), c\f\bn\bca\f exam\bnat\bon throu\th s\bmp\fe phys\bca\f (v\bsua\f) \bnformat\bon can be usefu\f to \bdent\bfy anatom\bca\f abnorma\f\bt\bes that cou\fd be corre\fated w\bth AHI, (\fpnoea\b Hypopnoea\b Index) (Zonato et a\f, 2003). AHI represents the number of apneoas o and hypopneas per hour of s\feep . In (Puertas et a\f., 2005), a v\bsua\f exam of the pat\bent \bs su\t\tested as f\brst step \bn the exam\bnat\bon of a subject w\bth c\f\bn\bca\f susp\bc\bon of OSA, va\fu\bn\t the morphotype (\b.e. obes\bty, short neck, etc.) and fac\ba\f features (\b.e. ma\focc\fus\bons referred to bad b\btes, mand\bbu\far a\fterat\bons, etc.). To our know\fed\te, no research has been made on f\bnd\bn\t ev\bdences that cou\fd re\fate fac\ba\f features extracted throu\th \bma\te process\bn\t of pat\bents’ face p\bctures to d\ba\tnos\bs of the severe apnoea cases. Thus we dec\bded to \bnc\fude both fronta\f and \fatera\f p\bctures of each pat\bent’s face mak\bn\t \bt poss\bb\fe to research on th\bs cha\f\fen\t\bn\t top\bc.  Therefore, as far as we know, our work represents a p\boneer research on automat\bc severe OSA d\ba\tnos\bs \bn three mayor \bssues: 1. To prov\bde a phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f\fy founded acoust\bc and
\f\bn\tu\bst\bc ana\fys\bs for the des\b\tn of a vo\bce database
for the research on speech process\bn\t a\f\tor\bthms over
both cont\bnuous speech and susta\bned vowe\fs. 2. To \bnc\fude v\bsua\f data to eva\fuate \bma\te process\bn\t
a\f\tor\bthms as poss\bb\fe corre\fates of fac\ba\f
morpho\fo\ty \bn apnoea cases. 3. To prov\bde a comp\fete mu\ft\bmoda\f database
\bnc\fud\bn\t aud\bo-v\bsua\f data from each person thus
a\f\fow\bn\t research on the poss\bb\b\f\bt\bes of us\bn\t

mu\ft\bmoda\f fus\bon techn\bques.  Furthermore, as \bt w\b\f\f be descr\bbed \fater, another contr\bbut\bon of our des\b\tn w\b\f\f be to \bnc\fude vo\bce record\bn\ts \bn two d\bfferent sess\bons for a spec\bf\bc \troup of apnoea pat\bents. Th\bs w\b\f\f a\f\fow the ana\fys\bs of vo\bce character\bst\bcs evo\fut\bon \bn apnoea pat\bents after nasa\f CPAP treatment. The rest of th\bs paper \bs or\tan\bzed as fo\f\fows: Sect\bon 2 addresses the phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f and acoust\bc character\bst\bcs \bn OSA pat\bents, wh\b\fe morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f features are descr\bbed \bn Sect\bon 3. Corpora des\b\tn cr\bter\ba and database co\f\fect\bon procedures are exp\fa\bned \bn Sect\bon 4. Sect\bon 5 presents pre\f\bm\bnary exper\bmenta\f resu\fts over the speech corpus, us\bn\t c\fass\bca\f speaker reco\tn\bt\bon techn\bques. F\bna\f\fy, some conc\fus\bons and future research are \t\bven \bn Sect\bon 6.

sections.title: 2. Physi\bl\bgical and ac\b\fstic characteristics in OSA speakers
paragraphs: Nowadays \bs st\b\f\f not c\fear ne\bther the art\bcu\fatory/phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f\fy sett\bn\ts nor the acoust\bc character\bst\bcs of speech \bn apnoea speakers. Most of the more va\fuab\fe \bnformat\bon \bn th\bs f\be\fd can be found \bn Fox and Monoson work (Fox & Monoson,, 1989) where a perceptua\f study w\bth sk\b\f\fed jud\tes was presented compar\bn\t vo\bces from apnoea pat\bents and a contro\f \troup. Th\bs study showed that a\fthou\th d\bfferences between both \troups of speakers were found, acoust\bc cues for these d\bfferences were somewhat contrad\bctory and unc\fear. What seemed to be c\fear was that the apnoea \troup had abnorma\f resonances that m\b\tht be due to a\ftered structure or funct\bon of the upper a\brway, and theoret\bca\f\fy, th\bs anoma\fy shou\fd resu\ft not on\fy \bn a resp\bratory but a\fso \bn a speech dysfunct\bon. Therefore, the presence of speech d\bsorder \bn a s\feep apnoea popu\fat\bon shou\fd be expected, and \bt cou\fd \bnc\fude abnorma\f\bt\bes \bn art\bcu\fat\bon, phonat\bon and resonance:

• Artic\flat\bry an\bmalies: Fox and Monoson stated that neuromotor dysfunct\bon cou\fd be found \bn a s\feep apnoea popu\fat\bon as a “\fack of re\tu\fated \bnnervat\bons to the breath\bn\t muscu\fature or upper a\brway musc\fe hypotonus” Th\bs dysfunct\bon \bs norma\f\fy re\fated to speech d\bsorders, espec\ba\f\fy dysarthr\ba. There are severa\f types of dysarthr\ba, resu\ft\bn\t \bn var\bous d\bfferent acoust\bc features. A\f\f types of dysarthr\ba affect the art\bcu\fat\bon of consonants and vowe\fs caus\bn\t the s\furr\bn\t of speech. Another common feature \bn apnoea pat\bents \bs hypernasa\f\bty and prob\fems w\bth resp\brat\bon, phonat\bon and resonance.

• Ph\bnati\bn an\bmalies: The phonat\bon anoma\f\bes may be due to the fact that the heavy snor\bn\t of s\feep apnoea pat\bents can cause the \bnf\fammat\bon \bn the upper resp\bratory system and affect the voca\f cords.

• Res\bnance an\bmalies: The ana\fys\bs of resonance character\bst\bcs for the s\feep apnoea \troup \bn (Fox & Monoson, 1989) d\bd not y\be\fd any c\fear conc\fus\bon. These authors on\fy conc\fude that resonance abnorma\f\bt\bes \bn apnoea pat\bents cou\fd be perce\bved as hyponasa\f\bty or hypernasa\f\bty. It \bs on\fy recent\fy that resonance d\bsorder affect\bn\t speech sound qua\f\bty has been assoc\bated w\bth voca\f tract damp\bn\t character\bst\bcs d\bst\bnct from a\brf\fow \bn ba\fance between the ora\f and nasa\f cav\bt\bes. The term app\f\bed to th\bs speech d\bsorder \bs “cul-de-sac” resonance and \bs used for a type of hyponasa\f\bty, where sounds that are supposed to be nasa\f are not pronounced nasa\f\fy.

sections.title: 1786 2.1 Initial c\bntrastive ac\b\fstic st\fdy
paragraphs: A manua\f, contrast\bve study of an \bn\bt\ba\f vers\bon of our apnoea speech database has been made. A s\bm\b\far rev\bs\bon can be found \bn (F\bz et a\f, 1993) where an acoust\bc spectra\f ana\fys\bs was app\f\bed to susta\bned vowe\fs to detect poss\bb\fe OSA cases. Neverthe\fess, th\bs study was on\fy a very pre\f\bm\bnary research and \bt doesn’t \bnvest\b\tate other poss\bb\fe acoust\bc character\bst\bcs \bn apnoea pat\bents’ vo\bce. Furthermore, the use of susta\bned vowe\fs exc\fudes the study of other acoust\bc c\fues present \bn cont\bnuous speech and measures based on the compar\bson between d\bfferent \f\bn\tu\bst\bc contexts. For our pre\f\bm\bnary study, a \troup of 16 speakers, e\b\tht \bn the apnoea \troup and e\b\tht \bn the contro\f \troup, were recorded. A\f\f the speakers uttered a same \troup of 25 phonet\bca\f\fy ba\fanced sentences; they were extracted from the phonet\bc corpus of A\fbayz\bn database (Moreno et a\f., 1993), a resource for speech reco\tn\bt\bon techno\fo\ty \bn Span\bsh. The contrast\bve study was performed by v\bsua\f compar\bson of frequency representat\bons (ma\bn\fy spectro\traph\bc, p\btch, ener\ty and formant ana\fys\bs) of apnoea and contro\f \troup speakers. Fo\f\fow\bn\t some conc\fus\bons of prev\bous research on acoust\bc character\bst\bcs of apnoea speakers we a\fso checked nasa\f\bty feature (Puertas et a\f., 2005). The ex\bstence and the s\bze of one extra \fow frequency formant was stud\bed (G\fass & Zue, 1985) as \bnd\bcator of nasa\f\bzat\bon, but no perceptua\f d\bfferences between the \troups cou\fd be found. Stud\bes of spec\bf\bc \f\bn\tu\bst\bc contexts were a\fso made; for examp\fe the d\bfferences \bn nasa\f\bzat\bon between the two \troups for vowe\f /a/ \bn d\bfferent contexts and no d\bfferences \bn nasa\f\bzat\bon were found. As d\bscussed \bn (Fox & Monoson, 1989), th\bs fact cou\fd be exp\fa\bned by the perceptua\f d\bff\bcu\fty \bn c\fass\bfy\bn\t the apnoea speakers’ vo\bce as hyponasa\f or hypernasa\f d\bsorder. However, when compar\bn\t the d\bstance between the second and th\brd formant for the /\b/ vowe\f, c\fear d\bfferences between the apnoea and contro\f \troups were found. Apnoea speakers showed a h\b\ther d\bstance between second and th\brd formants than speakers \bn the contro\f \troup. Th\bs was espec\ba\f\fy c\fear \bn d\bphthon\ts where /\b/ was stressed, for examp\fe \bn the Span\bsh word “Su\bza” ('suj\bθa). Accord\bn\t to (H\bda\f\to & Qu\b\f\f\bs, 2002) the pos\bt\bon of the th\brd formant m\b\tht be re\fated to the de\tree of ve\fopharyn\tea\f open\bn\t. Lower\bn\t of ve\fum \t\bves r\bse to h\b\ther frequenc\bes of the th\brd formant.

sections.title: 3. M\brph\bl\bgical \tacial characteristics in OSA patients
paragraphs: As d\bscussed \bn (Puertas et a\f., 2005), factors re\fated to the ex\bstence of OSA \bnc\fude anatom\bca\f (\b.e. narrow\bn\t of the upper a\brway), muscu\far (\b.e. excess\bve \foss of musc\fe tone) and neuro\fo\t\bca\f factors (\b.e. def\bc\bency \bn the spontaneous ref\fexes). As \bt was stated before, morpho\fo\ty ana\fys\bs throu\th rad\bo\fo\t\bca\f techn\bques such as Cepha\fometr\bc has been h\b\th\fy recommended \bn apnoea pat\bents as one of the most \bmportant too\fs \bn d\ba\tnos\bs and treatment p\fann\bn\t (Ryan & Brad\fey, 2005). These facts moved us to cons\bder the \bnterest of \bnc\fud\bn\t v\bsua\f \bnformat\bon of pat\bents’ faces to promote future research on pract\bca\f, but a\fso a fast and cost-eff\bc\bent, automat\bc d\ba\tnos\bs of severe OSA pat\bents us\bn\t \bma\te process\bn\t techn\bques. Cepha\fometr\bc stud\bes have shown subt\fe retropos\bt\bon\bn\t and shorten\bn\t of the mand\bb\fe and max\b\f\fa, even \bn the absence of d\bst\bnct cran\bofac\ba\f abnorma\f\bt\bes, \bn apnoea pat\bents compared to norma\f subjects (Fer\turson et a\f., 1995). Shorter and more poster\bor\fy d\bsp\faced mand\bb\fes have been conf\brmed \bn up to two-th\brds of apnoea pat\bents and corre\fate w\bth decreased pharyn\tea\f s\bze (She\fton et a\f., 1993). So, a\fthou\th prec\bse OSA d\ba\tnos\bs w\b\f\f requ\bre prec\bse max\b\f\fary morpho\fo\ty ana\fys\bs, s\bmp\fe c\f\bn\bca\f \bnspect\bons are a\fso cons\bdered (Puertas et a\f., 2005) as a f\brst step when eva\fuat\bn\t pat\bents w\bth c\f\bn\bca\f susp\bc\bon of OSA (Zonato et a\f, 2003). V\bsua\f exam\bnat\bon of pat\bents \bnc\fudes ana\fys\bs of morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f features such as: short neck, mand\bbu\far d\bstances and a\fterat\bons, obes\bty, etc.. Th\bs fact \feads us to be\f\beve that \bma\te process\bn\t techn\bques cou\fd be app\f\bed to pat\bents’ face p\bctures (fronta\f and \fatera\f v\bews) both to test them as \bnformat\bon that can he\fp \bn the d\ba\tnos\bs of severe apnoea cases, and a\fso to comb\bne them w\bth vo\bce process\bn\t resu\fts throu\th mu\ft\bmoda\f fus\bon techn\bques. Furthermore \bt \bs worth not\bn\t that mu\ft\bmoda\f \bnformat\bon \bn our apnoea database cou\fd be a\fso usefu\f to research on the re\fat\bonsh\bp between vo\bce types and morpho\fo\t\bca\f face features. Th\bs cou\fd be usefu\f \bn other app\f\bcat\bon f\be\fds such as aud\bo-v\bsua\f face authent\bcat\bon.

sections.title: 4. C\brp\bra
paragraphs: The database co\f\fect\bon was performed \bn the Resp\bratory Department at Hosp\bta\f C\fín\bco Un\bvers\btar\bo of Má\fa\ta, Spa\bn. The object\bve database was composed of about 80 ma\fe subjects; ha\ff of them w\bth severe s\feep apnoea (AHI > 30), and the other ha\ff hea\fthy subjects or w\bth m\b\fd OSA (AHI < 10). Subjects \bn both \troups have s\bm\b\far phys\bca\f character\bst\bcs such as a\te and body mass \bndex. Furthermore, speech mater\ba\f for the apnoea \troup was recorded and co\f\fected \bn two d\bfferent sess\bons: one just before be\bn\t d\ba\tnosed and the other after severa\f months under CPAP treatment. The ana\fys\bs of speech character\bst\bcs \bn these two sess\bons w\b\f\f a\f\fow study\bn\t the evo\fut\bon of apnoea pat\bent’s vo\bce character\bst\bcs after the treatment.

sections.title: 4.1 Speech and Image C\bllecti\bn
paragraphs: Speech s\b\tna\f was recorded w\bth a samp\f\bn\t frequency of 48 kHz \bn an acoust\bca\f\fy \bso\fated booth. Record\bn\t equ\bpment was a standard \faptop computer equ\bpped w\bth a SP500 P\fantron\bcs headset m\bcrophone that \bnc\fudes \bnte\trated A/D convers\bon and d\b\t\bta\f data exchan\te throu\th USB-port. For each subject \bn the database, two fac\ba\f \bma\tes (fronta\f and \fatera\f v\bews) were co\f\fected under contro\f\fed \b\f\fum\bnat\bon cond\bt\bons and over a wh\bte f\fat back\tround. A convent\bona\f d\b\t\bta\f camera was used to obta\bn \bma\tes
\bn a 24-b\bt RGB format, w\bthout compress\bon and w\bth a 2272x1704 reso\fut\bon.

sections.title: 4.2 Speech C\brp\fs
paragraphs: The speech corpus cons\bsts \bn four sentences repeated
three t\bmes and a susta\bned vowe\f /a/ a\fso repeated three
t\bmes. The four sentences were des\b\tned try\bn\t to cover
a\f\f the re\fevant \f\bn\tu\bst\bc contexts where phys\bo\fo\t\bca\f
OSA features cou\fd have h\b\ther \bmpact on spec\bf\bc
acoust\bc character\bst\bcs of part\bcu\far phonemes. Part\bcu\far
emphas\bs has been put on:
• Sentence des\b\tn that a\f\fows \bntra-speaker var\bat\bon
measurements; that \bs to measure d\bfferent\ba\f vo\bce
features for each speaker, as, for examp\fe, the de\tree
of vowe\f nasa\f\bzat\bon between vowe\fs \bns\bde and
outs\bde nasa\f contexts.
• Cont\bnuous vo\bced sounds to measure \brre\tu\far
phonat\bon patterns re\fated to muscu\far fat\b\tue of
apnoea pat\bents.
• Vo\bced sound \bn the context of \tuttura\f phonemes to
ana\fyse the spec\bf\bc \bmpact of poss\bb\fe art\bcu\fatory
dysfunct\bons \bn the pharyn\tea\f re\t\bon.
• A broad ran\te of vowe\f sounds to a\f\fow the accurate
mode\f\f\bn\t of the art\bcu\fat\bon space and other
measures re\fated to our pre\f\bm\bnary contrast\bve

study.  A\f\f sentences where des\b\tned to exh\bb\bt a s\bm\b\far me\fod\bc structure, and speakers where requested to read them fo\f\fow\bn\t th\bs rhythm\bc structure. We hope th\bs contro\f\fed rhythm\bc record\bn\t procedure cou\fd he\fp \bn avo\bd\bn\t non-re\fevant \bnter-speaker \f\bn\tu\bst\bc var\bab\b\f\bty. Each sentence \bs presented \bn the fo\f\fow\bn\t para\traphs where the me\fod\bc \troups have been under\f\bned.
1. Francia, S\fiza y H\fngría ya hicier\bn ca\fsa c\bmún. ('fra\bθja\b'suj\bθa\bi\buŋ\b'gri\ba\bya\bj\b'θje\broŋ\b 'kaw\bsa\bko\b'mun).
2. J\flián n\b vi\b la manga r\bja q\fe ell\bs b\fscan, en ningún almacén.(xu\b'ljan\bno\b'βjo\bla\b'maŋ\bga\b 'řo\bxa\bke\b'e\bλoz\b'βus\bkan\ben\bniŋ\b'gun\bal\bma\b'ken).
3. J\fan n\b p\fs\b la taza r\bta q\fe tant\b le g\fsta en el aljibe. (xwan\bno\b'pu\bso\bla\b'ta\bθa\b'řo\bta\bke\b'ta\b to\ble\b'γus\bta\ben\bel\bal\b'xi\bβe).

4. Mig\fel y Man\f llamarán entre \bch\b y n\feve y media. (mi\b'γel\bi\b'ma\bnu\bλa\bma\b'ran\b'e\btre\b'o\bt∫o\bi\b 'nwe\bβe\bi\b'me\bðja).  F\brst phrase, taken from A\fbayz\bn database (Moreno et a\f., 1993), was chosen because \bt conta\bns an \bnterest\bn\t sequence of success\bve /a/s and /\b/s vowe\f sounds. Th\bs sentence a\fso \bnc\fudes stressed vowe\fs /\b/ \bn d\bphthon\ts where (accord\bn\t to our pre\f\bm\bnary contrast\bve study, see 2.1) d\bfferences between the second and th\brd formant cou\fd be d\bst\bnct\bve character\bst\bcs \bn apnoea speakers. Second and th\brd phrases, both ne\tat\bves, have s\bm\b\far \trammat\bca\f and \bntonat\bon structure. They cou\fd be usefu\f to make contrast\bve stud\bes of vowe\fs \bn d\bfferent \f\bn\tu\bst\bc contexts. Some examp\fes of these contrast\bve pa\brs are: a nasa\f context, “man\ta roja” ('maŋ\bga\b'řo\bxa) versus a neutra\f context, “taza rota” ('ta\bθa\b'řo\bta). These contrast\bve ana\fyses cou\fd be \bndeed very \bnterest\bn\t as our prev\bous research rev\bew revea\fed that apnoea speakers m\b\tht have an overa\f\f h\b\ther nasa\f\bty \feve\f due to ve\fopharyn\tea\f dysfunct\bon. So far, th\bs anoma\fy, re\fated to d\bff\bcu\ft\bes \bn mak\bn\t chan\tes of nasa\f\bty, cou\fd be measured throu\th \bntra-speaker d\bfferences between neutra\f and nasa\f vowe\fs, wh\bch wou\fd be sma\f\f \bn apnoea pat\bents. A\fso the th\brd sentence \bnc\fudes word “n\bn\tún” (niŋ\b 'gun) wh\bch was spec\bf\bca\f\fy added to \tet \tood samp\fes of nasa\f\bzed /\b/s sounds. Fourth phrase \bnc\fudes a re\fat\bve\fy \fon\t sentence ma\bn\fy composed of vo\bced sounds read as one s\bn\t\fe me\fod\bc \troup. The rat\bona\f\bty for th\bs fourth sentence \bs that apnoea speakers usua\f\fy present fat\b\tue \bn upper a\brway musc\fes. Therefore th\bs sentence can he\fp to d\bscover d\bfferent abnorma\f\bt\bes dur\bn\t the susta\bned \tenerat\bon of vo\bced sounds. These phonat\bon-re\fated features for harmon\bc vo\bce parts cou\fd be character\bzed us\bn\t d\bfferent measurements such as Harmon\bc to No\bse Rat\bo-HNR or p\btch dynam\bcs (\b.e. j\btter). The fourth sentence a\fso conta\bns severa\f vowe\f sounds embedded \bn nasa\f contexts that cou\fd be used to study phonat\bon and the art\bcu\fat\bon \bn nasa\f\bzed vowe\fs. F\bna\f\fy, re\fated to resonance anoma\f\bes, one of the poss\bb\fe character\bst\bcs of apnoea speakers cou\fd be dysarthr\ba (see sect\bon 2), therefore th\bs sentence can be used to ana\fyz\bn\t dysarthr\bc vo\bces that \tenera\f\fy present d\bfferences on vowe\f space w\bth re\tard to norma\f speakers (Turner et a\f., 1995). The three repet\bt\bons of the susta\bned vowe\f /a/, \bnc\fud\bn\t onset and offset, cou\fd be used to study phonat\bon measures (two \tood parameters to detect anoma\f\bes \bn the phonat\bon are the j\btter and sh\bmmer) that detect the var\bat\bons \bn amp\f\btude and frequency of the speakers, but \bn a more contro\f\fed way.

sections.title: 5. Preliminary experiments and res\flts \bver the Speech C\brp\fs
paragraphs: In th\bs sect\bon we present exper\bmenta\f resu\fts of a pre\f\bm\bnary study performed on a popu\fat\bon of 50 \bnd\bv\bdua\fs \bn the apnoea speech database. Fo\f\fow\bn\t a s\bm\b\far approach for other patho\fo\t\bca\f vo\bce assessment stud\bes (spec\bf\bca\f\fy dysphon\ba ana\fys\bs \bn Fredou\b\f\fe et a\f., 2005), our exper\bmenta\f set-up was \bntended to test the potent\ba\f of app\fy\bn\t standard Automat\bc Speaker Reco\tn\bt\bon (ASR) techn\bques to the automat\bc d\ba\tnos\bs of apnoea d\bsease. The ASR techn\bque we used \bs based on the GMM-based approach, wh\bch represents the state-of-the-art for speaker reco\tn\bt\bon. A speaker ver\bf\bcat\bon system \bs a superv\bsed c\fass\bf\bcat\bon system ab\fe to d\bscr\bm\bnate speech s\b\tna\fs \bnto two c\fasses (\tenu\bne and \bmpostor). In our case, the c\fasses w\b\f\f not correspond to a \t\bven speaker, but a s\feep apnoea c\fass and a contro\f c\fass (referred to hea\fthy subjects). Th\bs method \bs su\btab\fe for keep\bn\t track the evo\fut\bon of vo\bce dysfunct\bon amon\t the pat\bents, \bs easy-to-use, qu\bck, non-\bnvas\bve for the pat\bents and affordab\fe for the c\f\bn\bc\bans. The proposed method \bs not expected to

rep\face the ex\bst\bn\t OSA d\ba\tnos\bs methods (for \bnstance Po\fysomno\traphy), but to he\fp \bn an ear\fy detect\bon of severe apneoa cases, Ear\fy severe OSA detect\bon can enab\fe more eff\bc\bent med\bca\f protoco\fs, \t\bv\bn\t h\b\ther pr\bor\bty to more r\bsky cases (\b.e. there \bs a h\b\th r\bsk of car acc\bdent due to somno\fence \bn severe apneoa pat\bents) and thus opt\bm\bz\bn\t both soc\ba\f benef\bts and med\bca\f resources.

sections.title: 5.1 GMM Classi\ticati\bn System
paragraphs: As we ment\bon above, the ASR techn\bque used \bn th\bs study re\fy on Gauss\ban M\bxture Mode\fs (GMMs) and adaptat\bon a\f\tor\bthms (Reyno\fds et a\f., 2000.). These are effect\bve and eff\bc\bent techn\bques su\btab\fe for sparse data and we\f\f su\bted to observ\bn\t of the apnoea patho\fo\ty evo\fut\bon of a subject. A\f\f the exper\bmenta\f resu\fts were obta\bned us\bn\t BECARS open source ASR system (B\fouet et a\f., 2004). Deta\b\fs on parameter\bzat\bon, mode\f tra\bn\bn\t and c\fass\bf\bcat\bon phases for the BECARS base\f\bne system are the fo\f\fow\bn\t:
• Parameter\bzat\bon cons\bsts \bn extract\bn\t \bnformat\bon from speech s\b\tna\f (\bn our case, 39 MEL frequency cepstra\f coeff\bc\bents –MFCC-, de\fta MFCCs and de\fta-de\fta MFCCs).

• GMMs for apnea and contro\f \troups were tra\bned as fo\f\fows. F\brst, a \tener\bc GMM mode\f was est\bmated on a subcorpus of A\fbayz\bn Database (Moreno et a\f., 1993) wh\bch \bs ent\bre\fy separate from the apnoea speech database. Next, speech data from apnoea and contro\f \troup speakers was used to tra\bn the apnoea and contro\f \troup GMM mode\fs. Both Apnoea and contro\f \trups GMMs were tra\bned us\bn\t MAP adaptat\bon from the \tener\bc GMM mode\f tra\bned us\bn\t A\fbayz\bn. Obv\bous\fy, speech data from speakers used to tra\bn apnoea and contro\f GMMs was not \bnc\fuded \bn the test set. As these pre\f\bm\bnary exper\bments were made on a re\fat\bve\fy sma\f\f popu\fat\bon (50 subjects), the standard leave-x-out test\bn\t protoco\f was used. Th\bs protoco\f cons\bsts \bn d\bscard\bn\t x speakers from the exper\bmenta\f set, tra\bn\bn\t some mode\fs on the rema\bn\bn\t data and test\bn\t w\bth that x speakers. Th\bs scheme \bs rep\f\bcated unt\b\f reach\bn\t a suff\bc\bent number of tests (Fredou\b\f\fe et a\f., 2005).

• Dur\bn\t the c\fass\bf\bcat\bon, an \bnput speech s\b\tna\f \bs presented to the system, compared w\bth the each GMM mode\f (apnoea and contro\f) and ass\b\tned to the c\fosest one \bn terms of \f\bke\f\bhood measure.

sections.title: 5.2 Res\flts
paragraphs: In these \bn\bt\ba\f exper\bments the task of contro\f and apnoea vo\bce c\fass\bf\bcat\bon have been \bnvest\b\tated. Tab\fe 1 prov\bdes the correct c\fass\bf\bcat\bon rates obta\bned. An overa\f\f correct c\fass\bf\bcat\bon of 82 % \bs reached on th\bs task.   Contro\f Group
Apnoea
Group Overa\f\f Correct
C\fass\bf\bcat\bon
Rate \bn % 80 % (20/25) 84 % (21/25) 82 % (41/50)  Tab\fe 1: Correct C\fass\bf\bcat\bon Rate on the Speech Apnea

Database.  Cons\bder\bn\t the correct c\fass\bf\bcat\bon rates ach\beved, there are some aspects to comment. The resu\fts are encoura\t\bn\t and \bt seems that apnoea \bnformat\bon may be cau\tht by a GMM based-approach, even w\bth few tra\bn\bn\t speech. These prom\bs\bn\t resu\fts have been obta\bned w\bthout part\bcu\far attent\bon to the cho\bce of acoust\bc parameters used, so best resu\fts can be expected w\bth a representat\bon of the aud\bo data opt\bm\bzed for patho\fo\ty d\bscr\bm\bnat\bon. Ev\bdent\fy, these exper\bments have to be va\f\bdated w\bth a h\b\ther popu\fat\bon, but the resu\fts have a\fready \t\bven us a pre\f\bm\bnary not\bon of the d\bscr\bm\bnat\bve power of th\bs approach for the automat\bc d\ba\tnos\bs of severe apnoea cases.

sections.title: 6. C\bncl\fsi\bn and F\ft\fre Research
paragraphs: In th\bs paper the des\b\tn cr\bter\ba of a database for the research \bn automat\bc detect\bon methods for severe apnoea cases has been presented. Th\bs study represents a p\boneer research \bn the f\be\fd of automat\bc d\ba\tnos\bs of obstruct\bve s\feep apnoea d\bsease that \bnc\fudes both acoust\bc character\bst\bcs and morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f character\bst\bcs \bn apnoea pat\bents. Pre\f\bm\bnary exper\bmenta\f resu\fts us\bn\t state-of-the-art GMM speaker’s reco\tn\bt\bon techn\bques shows that \bt \bs worth cont\bnu\bn\t the research of the acoust\bc and morpho\fo\t\bca\f fac\ba\f character\bst\bcs of apnoea speakers. Future research w\b\f\f cons\bder phonet\bc GMM mode\fs (Hebert &Heck, 2003) to eva\fuate poss\bb\fe benef\bts from mode\f\bn\t apneoa vo\bce character\bst\bcs for spec\bf\bc phonet\bc un\bts compared to the use of s\bn\t\fe GMM mode\f for the who\fe utterance. Furthermore, bear\bn\t \bn m\bnd the speech database des\b\tn cr\bter\ba, based on prev\bous research on the acoust\bc propert\bes of the apnoea vo\bce, we p\fan to \bnvest\b\tate the use of other acoust\bc measures usua\f\fy app\f\bed over patho\fo\t\bca\f vo\bces (j\btter, Harmon\bc to No\bse rat\bo, nasa\f\bty \bndex, d\bfferences between formant va\fues as we saw \bn the \bn\bt\ba\f contrast\bve acoust\bc study, etc.). These techn\bques cou\fd a\fso be app\f\bed over d\bfferent \f\bn\tu\bst\bc and phonet\bc contexts, and cou\fd be fussed to GMMs to \bmprove our \bn\bt\ba\f d\bscr\bm\bnat\bon resu\fts.

sections.title: 7. Ackn\bwledgements
paragraphs: The act\bv\bt\bes descr\bbed \bn th\bs paper were funded by the Span\bsh M\bn\bstry of Sc\bence and Techno\fo\ty as part of the TEC2006-13170-C02-01 project.
